content.line: What did you do last night?
content.speaker: John

content.line: My wife told me a story.
content.speaker: Jake

options.line: Bedtime stories. Practice for when we have a child.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: She does that. And I lay my head in her lap.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only when it's a full moon.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only on the first night she bleeds.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only when I'm a good boy.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only when she is drunk.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only when I can't sleep.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only after she comes.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Only on the anniversary of her father's death.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: My wife never tells me stories. Nothing ever happens in her life.
options.speaker: John

options.line: My wife never tells me stories. We operate through a sign language of sorts.
options.speaker: John

options.line: My wife never tells me stories. Except where I'm the clumsy villain.
options.speaker: John

options.line: My wife never tells me stories. Except for the old ones.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Apart from you.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Jane sometimes never speaks. She just is.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: You always said she had an inventive turn of mind.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: And you try to listen as if it's the first time.
options.speaker: Jake

content.line: Only my wife couldn't finish her story.
content.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because it wasn't a full moon last night. Her mind only swims in moonlight.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because it wasn't a full moon last night. Her stories are born in the cradle of only the purest lunacy.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because it was just pink water last night. The sanitary towel rustled between her legs all night.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because it was just pink water last night. I woke up to the smell of blood.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because it was just pink water last night. Her stories are there only to heal her wound.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because I farted in bed last night. The unspoken conjugal right of a husband, I feel.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because I farted in bed last night. And she won't touch me all night for it.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Because I farted in bed last night. Its particular aroma reminded her of her father.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she threw up half way through. And guess who cleaned it up.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she threw up half way through. She made up for it in the morning though.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she threw up half way through. Maybe the alcohol or just an ending she wanted to avoid.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she managed she sent herself to sleep. I felt she had abandoned me.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she managed she sent herself to sleep. I like to hear her sleep. It is my lullaby.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she managed she sent herself to sleep. When I tried to wake her up, she bit me.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she had a sexual aftershock. God, aren't women weird.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she had a sexual aftershock. Aren't women incredibly lucky?
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she had a sexual aftershock. So she had to start again from scratch.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she suddenly remembered what he was really like. Words and disappointment do not mix.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she suddenly remembered what he was really like. His smile still haunts her.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Last night she suddenly remembered what he was really like. Then she looked at me, sighed and went straight to sleep.
options.speaker: Jake

parts.summary: Jake's wife tells him bedtime stories under certain circumstances.

content.line: Try again tonight. What kind of stories will your wife tell you?
content.speaker: John

default.line: She likes to castrate the prince.
default.speaker: Jake

options.line: The princess does it. With her teeth.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: His mother usually ends up doing it while he's asleep.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: His father does it out of jealousy. He wants the princess for himself.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: He does it to himself when he hears the princess is with another.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Before she says he changes into the beast.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The princess doesn't just prick her finger.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: For my wife the world of magic is opened with sex.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: In narrative her sexuality has no limits.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The woman betrays and the man forgives.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The man betrays and the woman forgives.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Her stories are always about redemption through pain.
options.speaker: Jake

default.line: They always end happily ever after.
default.speaker: Jake

options.line: We both like to believe in happy endings. For ourselves most of all.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The lovers, that is. They deny their own fears in the presence of the other.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The lovers, that is. They affirm their own existence in the presence of the other.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Happy endings are fiction's greatest invention.
options.speaker: Jake

default.line: They send me sweetly to sleep. Why should I care?
default.speaker: Jake

options.line: They lubricate my dreams with innocence.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Such stories are for children. What is she trying to tell me?
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: I just close my eyes and think of mother.
options.speaker: Jake

default.line: It's the prince who gets rescued for her.
default.speaker: Jake

options.line: From a life in which he does not need to acheive.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: From the spell his mother put him in.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: By an Amazon queen so she can take his seed.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: When we briefly became the person we could be for the person we could never have.
options.speaker: John

options.line: When love was sweet and Jane most absent.
options.speaker: John

options.line: When your wife was a world of new possibilities.
options.speaker: John

options.line: I should've done her once or twice and left it at that.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Before you end up hating the fact that you love her so much.
options.speaker: John

options.line: When we saw ourselves as angels and believed it was really us.
options.speaker: John

options.line: When what was sweet is now just grotesque.
options.speaker: John

options.line: When she had a perfect arse.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Tragic, I tell you. Tragic.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Sad or what?
options.speaker: John

options.line: How completely idiotic.
options.speaker: John

options.line: We found a solution to that. We became mutual parasites. That way if one of you leaves, you both die.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: I remember first thinking about Jane when I was three.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Not a prison of old ones.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Sexual convenience comes at a price.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Or loving the fact that you hate her so much.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Marriage is an act of faith, the hardest of spirtual disciplines.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: We can forgive a pretty face almost anything.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: A decent pair of buttocks are not hard to find, John.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Meet the mother. If you can imagine doing it with her, you're made for life.
options.speaker: Jake

parts.summary: Jake describes the kind of bedtime stories his wife tells him.

options.line: Jane. Her fantasy is quite extraordinary.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Jane. Her fantasy is hard to duplicate.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Jane. Her fantasy begins on the edge of terror.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: There's no one like Jane.
options.speaker: John

options.line: There's a bit of Jane in all of us.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her stories never really end. You know, in a tidy little knot at the end.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: They contradict themselves like dreams.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: The most innocent and the most cruel.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: They round and round in circles. Like we all do.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: They splinter like remote controlled TV.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: She has no need of stories herself. She creates them wherever she goes.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Greek myths meet science fiction. Men as the heroic and redundant species.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Her storybook is her own version of history.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over. Their focus not even within but totally elsewhere.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over. Fixed like a totem. Commanding and indifferent.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over as she sees all the stories at once.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over. A self-inflicted blindness she cures with language.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over and her pupils shrink to a full stop.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over and you vanish in the impersonal stare.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her eyes get glazed over when the narrative narcotic kicks in.
options.speaker: John

options.line: I get mesmerised by the movement of her lips.
options.speaker: John

options.line: I get mesmerised by the cadence falling from her lips.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her voice is the sound of a litany.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Her voice is how a woman should really sound.
options.speaker: John

options.line: But her kiss is cold like Judas.
options.speaker: John

options.line: And her kiss haunts you. Like ecstasy.
options.speaker: John

options.line: Red waves undulating over vowels. Teeth biting on consonants.
options.speaker: John

options.line: I forget what she is saying and yet I understand.
options.speaker: John

options.line: The only thing language can do is surrender.
options.speaker: John

options.line: And she can scream like a Banshee.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Amen. And when you respond you respond on behalf of all men.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: A voice you and close to eyes to and listen.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: A mother talking beautifully to her child.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: And she sleeps with her eyes wide open.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: A delicious kiss that bends you into submission.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: And you whole life beomes a kind of purgatory towards another moment like that.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: But her affections are quite the carnivore. They feed on your worship.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: No, it's her hands. When she touches me I get so happy inside.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: No, it's her hands. Those graceful ambassadors to her state.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: I remember all that she said and yet I never understand.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Sometimes I wish I could forget some of the things she has said.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: Sometimes it falls like sweet rain, sometimes like a plague of curses.
options.speaker: Jake

options.line: And then take no prisoners.
options.speaker: Jake

parts.summary: They talk about the kind of stories that Jane tells.
